title: What's a good salary in UK? - Quora

response.answer_text: I lived in Norwich through the 1990’s. My mortgage was about £300 per month. I sold the house a few months too early. Its value skyrocketed, thanks to the completion of the M11 and the development near Carrow Road (Norwich City FC ground). So today that mortgage would be £1500 to £2000 per month. I wish I had not have sold it. I did without a car for a little while, but that was not feasible, especially when I did not have access to a company vehicle any more and the bicycle was doable when I was working in Cambridge and using the train. Bicycle at each terminal. So now you are looking at over £500 per month to run a car, and I liked having a motorcycle also. Then house repairs, utility bills and upkeep, with VAT, you are looking at £200 per month. Phone £50 per month. Food and beer, over £500 per month, clothing and sundries, £100 per month. I am not a natty dresser. And all that is not including my wife !! But at least there is a saving on health insurance, compared to the USA. So I would say easily £3000 per month, and that is not grand luxury. The VAT (value added tax) and the gosoline cost are a killer. That is why I cycled as much as possible and for distances, used a small, but fast motorcycle. My last motorcycle over there was a Suzuki GSX-R 400, which would do 125 mph and about 75 mpg Imperial gallon. That is about 60 mpg US gallon. I had to do that as I was typically working around 100 miles away from home. Sometimes more than that. If I had a small apartment, living in a way cheaper place than London, such as Norfolk, I could probably shave £1000 per month off of that. But I would say for a working, commuting person, it would be very difficult to live for less than £1500 per month. You need at least £2000 per month. That at the moment is about $3000 US. You would be in trouble living on that in a typical city, especially running a car and phaving to pay for your health insurance.

My opinion probably anything £25k up wards but it all depends on your spending habits ect. I earn just shy of 19k a year I have 3 children so me and my partner on top get what you'd call benefits/social assistance of about £1200 a month because of my low income. Our household would be classed as in poverty but we're not. We've got contracts phone we've got subscription TV services, new electrical items and a full fridge.i have a car on finance and two motorbikes. The kids never want for anything. To be honest it amazes me when people who earn more sit there and complain about lack of money. What are you doing. I know people that claim government assistance they're not entitled to they never have money in the bank yeh they're probably taking another £600 a month income then we are. They don't have a car or flashy stuff were does that go ? So yeh your wage is very dependent on management. I don't think it's too expensive to live in the UK and if you use common sense you can live comfortably on a smaller wage . So realistically a good salary depends on your circumstances unfortunately we're I live house prices are still reasonably high due to the fact were in a nice part of Suffolk and not that far from London . Renting is also extortionate at anywhere between £800-£1200+ for a three bed house. Were lucky and again have a council house so rent is very reasonable but if your on a low income and have a higher rent in certain circumstances the government will give you may state assistance to balance that out. It's all common sense really if it only two of you in house why are you renting 3 bed ? If you have children and are working then you can apply for state help to counter act the lower income. Some people may see get a better paid job but someone has gotta do it we can't all earn millions. I have a skilled job in a very small industry but still earn a crap wage even though it's would be alot harder to find the skill to replace me but I like my job so you also have to take into it your mental well-being.

I live in Portsmouth, on the South Coast I imagine up the North of England it's drastically cheaper but here is what we pay. A four bedroom home, cable, WiFi, landline, all utilities, car, car insurance, council tax, groceries, four mobile phones, my family of 6 costs about £1500 per month tops due to fluctuations, I could cut my budget to about £1,300 if necessary. This is for an immigrant family with no recourse to public funds, so I find it quite reasonable. For a British citizen receiving child benefit it's probably much better. You would want to earn at least £1,000 more a month to have disposable income, and enjoy life a bit, especially with lots of kids. I don't have much expectations to live a lavish lifestyle, I just want to pay my bills and enjoy a drive, a nice meal or a holiday. My work is just above minimum wage and it can cover almost all my monthly bills alone. So I think if you are a healthy person and able to get a basic job you can live. Don't be fooled by answers of people who are used to being rich they make it sound like living as a single person on £1,000 a month means begging for change and starving. My city has studios for £350 per month, if you earn minimum wage and get a £60 monthly bus pass you are pretty much almost £800 to spend on yourself for the rest of the month….thats pretty good. However if in outer london, a two bed flat could cost you £1400 per month, plus £800 for food, electricity, internet, gas, water, council tax, mobile line for a couple only. excluding transport which could vary between £60 per month to £300 per month per person that depends where you want to commute and what transportation to use. So if to budget your net and not gross income should be £2600 per month minimum if both working and no cash to spend on entertainment or clothing or holidays or leisure.

I’m going to talk about take home salary. This assumes you are living in a major city, and are a young person. £1000 - you live in a shared house, and shop at budget supermarkets. You use public transport (no car) and you have a couple of nights a month socialising. It’s not much fun, but it’s doable. (Salary of £13,000) £1500 per month. You live in a shared house. You have your own cheap second hand car. Your social life is ok, you do stuff most weekends. You will be able to have a couple of cheap holidays in UK/Europe a year. (Salary of £20,000) £2000 per month. You can either rent your own flat and and live the same as the £1500 per month person or keep living in a shared house and live a nice life with lots of luxuries. Or be sensible and save £500 a month. (salary of £30,000) £2500 per month. You’re starting to make enough money that you might be able to get a mortgage and buy some shitty flat if your parents have £50k lying around to give you as a deposit. If you’re stupid, you can probably afford to finance a brand new car, or go on some outrageous holidays to make your Instagram followers jealous. This is where life starts to actually be quite fun. (salary of £38,000) £3000 per month. You can no now actually serisouly look into buying a flat and maybe even saving the deposit yourself over a few years. You can easily rent your own place, and have a very nice lifestyle, go on some nice holidays, or have a nice new car (Mercedes, BMW etc.) Whatever luxuries you like you can probably have if you don’t go crazy. (Salary of £48,000) Beyond this, not a lot changes. You either make sensible investments with the rest or live a playboy lifestyle. If you want to buy an actual house in the UK (not a flat), and don’t have rich parents, you will need to earn significantly more than this, or have a partner with a good salary as well. The UK is a very expensive place to live, with good quality accommodation being hideously expensive these days. Down south, don’t expect to buy much of a house for less than £400,000 ($500,000USD). A good cheap flat can be had for around £200,000 ($250,000USD)

Depends on what you understand as a good salary. Is it one that provides all of your basic needs such as shelter, sustenance and energy needs? Do you mean one which provides for luxuries such as eating out at expensive restautants, international holidays, large luxury cars, expensive jewellery, yachts plus excess for investments etc. Or is it one which provides the maximum financial rewards which are well above those needs and desires. Of course it also depends on the cost of living when making comparisons you live in a high cost of living area such as the USA or a low cost one such as Costa Rica. In the UK an income of £25,000 ($32000) will suffice for basic needs and provide a little extra, a salary of $50000 ($64000) will provide for a very comfortable life, house ownership and a level of luxuries. Above these levels the sky is the limit. My wife is a self employed contractor and earns around £108,000 - £110,000 ($140,000 -$150,000 approx) which allows us a certain amout of luxury. These figures ar all PA of course. My pension is around £2,000 ($32,000) which would pay all of our bills and living expenses but little luxury if we had to depend upon it. But remember our cost of living overall is much less than the UK despite what the gainsayers will have you believe. Quote: By that broad measure, the cost of living in the U.K. is 6.51% lower than the cost of living in the United States. Rent overall is about 27% lower in the U.K. (NOTE: I would include rent in the overall cost of living as shelter is an important basic need. and average house prices are cheaper in the UK than the US.) Is it Cheaper to Live in the U.K. Than in the U.S.? This is an overall comparison taking the most expensive cities together with the poorest in both countries.

Depends where you want to live and what you call ENOUGH, what you are willing to sacrifice, how greedy you are, how far you are wiling to go to get what you NEED, not what you WANT. Plenty of folk, living n the streets or moving from place to place, living in caravans/mobile homes, with no fixed abode, making money where and when they can, not paying tax, since they are below the threshold… and remember there is a great deal of truth in the saying “Money doesn’t bring you happiness”.. I have met many very happy, smiling folk, from all walks of life, in many different countries and the happiest are those with very little in the way of material goods.. Food, clean water, good health and a roof over their head. To live anywhere, you do not need a house with a certain number or rooms, you do not need al the fancy tech and crap that the majority of the civilised world hankers after… That is not what I call LIVING, that is called keeping up with the Jones's. To live anywhere, you need only the basics. A roof over you head, be it a tent, caravan, shed, flat, house, barn whatever, a place to keep you out of the elements, where you can keep warm and where you are much safer than laying on the pavement or a park bench. Good health, mostly down to you to keep yourself in good condition, but when you do get sick or need medical attention, the UK is one of the best countries for you, as we have the NHS. Nobody gets turned away, as they do in the States, simply because they don’t have the money Food and clean water, obviously every single person alive today, needs to have both of these.. Yes there are many that don’t have access to one or the other or sometimes both Clothing.. Not absolutely necessary, depending on where you want to live, but in the UK, if you want to go out and not get arrested for indecent exposure, then clothing would be a good idea. Everything else, is called material or in my book, immaterial if you simply want to live. So the answer is, that there is no set number, no set amount, that you need to live in the UK, until you know hoe and where you want to live.. Yes the government has a minimum wage.. and there are plenty of materialistic folk, who would say that is not enough, but they have been raised in a society that simply want more and more, for less and less.

It depends on where you live. However I can give you reference of where I lived and you can compare with where you want to live using this website Cost of Living. Also this answer assumes you are an immigrant. I lived in Northampton, Northamptonshire and found upwards of 60K is a decent salary especially for an immigrant. 80K would be nice. Now the mean and median salaries in Northampton are much lower but as an immigrant, you have to build everything from scratch and that costs money. You can find mean and median salaries here at Northamptonshire Average salary, household income. Another factor to consider is age. You will need to catch up on the savings that otherwise you would have built if you started working soon after uni. This plays a role on, by when you can afford a deposit on a house etc. Breakdown of some the basic expenses: Rent for a 2 bed flat: 800 - 1000 Car: You can get a decent car for about 4K-6K Groceries : Roughly 250 - 400 for a 2–3 member household. Car Insurance: This is a real stinger for new drivers. About 1800 - 3000 County Tax: If I remember correctly, it was about 80 per month Utilities : Roughly 300 for water, electricity and internet Phone: 20–30 per month Entertainment: 100 - infinity :). Other expenses to consider are petrol, shopping, eating out etc. Hope this helps. Cheers!

a good idea might be gained by knowing that a person just out of uni with a 1 year teaching course after that will get a salary of 25000 (1700 a month after tax) in England. there is almost no job less paid than teaching for given graduate so anything less than that at age 23 or over and you aren’t doing well…. expect a 10k improvement over the next 5 years but not much afterwards in this career. I have had ex students going on Starting salaries of over 50k straight out of uni so it’s really not an easy answer to give but I assume that on anything over 30–35k you can live a settled, grown up, not scared of losing your job tomorrow and unable to eat kind of pretty happily in the UK (if not in London Itself). it’s all about industries though, I’ve spent a decade managing restaurants etc before going back to uni and in to teaching. As a General Manager of a restaurant business in a trendy part of London with up to 30 staff and 4million turnover a year i was making 30k-ish….the same as a teacher with 3 years under their belt.

I live in the outskirts of London on an average salary of £24000. Im a scientist an we’re typically underpaid. The rent on my 3 bed house is £1250 the council tax is about £250 The rest of my bills equate to about £200 on top not including food. paying £300 a month on a car zaps most of my budget. I would like to note that my living cost are split 50/50 between me and my partner. Living in and around London is very expensive if you’re renting. Me and said partner have been lucky enough to have families that have helped us with the deposit on a house, we’re moving an hour away from my work so that we can afford to buy a 3 bed house for £295,000- which for where we are is a great price. Our mortgage payments will be around £750 a month then onwards. If you can afford to put a deposit down, most places are affordable. I wouldn’t recommend renting if you can get away with it.

This kind of question seems like it could benefit from as many answers as possible, so I'll just answer you my story and it may help. The past four years I was a PhD student living in Edinburgh. I was earning a 'living allowance' of 14,000 per year, equalling about 1,200 per month, tax free. Rent is the biggest outgoing. Edinburgh is not a cheap city, especially for rent, but by shopping around I paid, at different times, 345 or 260 per month, and I lived in very 'trendy' places in the old town near the city center. Living further out you’d get these prices more easily. I started my four years with -£500. When I finished I had £18,000 saved. I went on one month long holiday to south East Asia, several ski trips, and I never said no to a beer. Basically, I lived a life that was frugal, but always enjoyable and never sacrificed my leisure spending. I was living alone and only had myself to support, but you can see that, even with a modest wage, that I would guess is equivalent to a full time minimum wage job, I had a lot of disposable income. Whenever I reflect on this, I feel immensely lucky to live in the country that I do :)

The cost of living varies significantly across the UK, largely driven by differences in property prices. As a guideline, based on work by a major poverty charity, a single person needs a minimum of around £850/month after tax excluding rent to have what most British people would consider a decent basic life. That includes some social activities, food, transport, clothing, and so on. You would not save any money, or travel internationally! You would clearly need to add rent to that to get the total after tax income required. You can use the Minimum Income Calculator to give you an estimate of an absolute floor, but be aware that rental costs can be very much higher if you live near London, and also bear in mind that you may not be eligible for some of the benefits the calculator assumes if you are not a current resident. The tool also allows you to identify the likely costs of different family sizes. I suggest that you identify the rental costs of wherever you are considering living, and work out a first stab at a budget based on that tool.

Certainly depends on where you live with some place's being a lot more expensive than others. I live about half an hour drive outside London and here you can live comfortable for about 25k a year, but most people earning that much will not own their own house, but you can rent a decent place. Everyone has a different idea of what a good salary is for me anything 25k plus is good, for this I can afford nice flat, nice food, holidays. For others would have to 40k plus to be considered a good salary.

In the North of England you’ll need to take home around £1200 a month. That will pay all your bills in a decent apartment block and give you a reasonable social life, no foriegn holidays, if you like nightlife you could probably afford to go out twice a month. That’s assuming you are living alone and not running a car and are clear of debt. That is primarily in working class areas, affluent boroughs the rent will go up considerably. I know people who live alone only taking home a grand, but they struggle and live in crap apartments in poor areas. If you want to live in a major City Centre apartment such as Manchester you’ll need another £300 on top, as rent is an extra £200 - £300 a month than in the suburbs or smaller town centres. If you have to ask, you probably can’t afford London and unless you are a very high earner its impossible to live there on your own. I’ve made it sound depressing but that is the absolute minimum to live. If you flat share or have a partner you’ll have a much better quality of life.

Average Family of 3, London/South East, 2 cars, mortgage/rent of 3/4 bed house. Monthly bills and food spend would be 2.5k-3k. This is just to cover the basics. Average rent/mortgage would be the biggest spend +/-1.5k Going out, buying clothes, holidays, car petrol, anything else is on top. Majority of the families will have 2 people working. Or one with a take home of minimum of 3k. Based on that, a good salary would be anything of 3k and up take home, which before tax would equal to 50k a year. If you live in the west country, midlands or up north, a good salary will be less, as mortgage/rent is cheaper.

All depends on where you live. My current take home pay is £1200 a month. Pretty shitty but for the work I do, in this area, it’s ok. My monthly bills, inc mortgage, car insurance, etc etc are £969. So, my salary is adequate. Overtime gives me money for me. I used to be on, until this year, a salary of £33k. Meant taking home £2k a month. With the same bills etc I was pretty well off. Good 500 quid spare each month, after food. House prices vary so much. If you’re wondering whether a salary for a new job is doable look at Rightmove for that area. I live in Lancashire. That £33pa would be MUCH less attractive in London.

Rather than answer his with a breakdown of what money goes where on the lacklustre salaries the UK has to offer I’ll just be honest and tell you that wage stagnation is a very real problem here in the UK and I’d advise looking into other countries if that option is available to you. You can be a very highly qualified person and very good in your field but the chances are this will not be reflected in salary and you’ll still just be living in a house share with other professionals in similar situations as living costs and inflation greatly exceed salary growth. If you want to look into this further just google “why are wages in the UK so low” - there’s lots of information out there. In all honesty, these days if you wanted to be able to buy a house and have what would be considered a nice middle-class life you’re going to need at least £50,000pa.

It's all on you. I live alone, have no social or sports outgoings and spend considerably more than the lady who posted her budget for a family of 6. I used to know a fellow who made his meals and froze them once per week in a batch. Everything is dependent on you when it comes to outgoings… How nice a house do you want ? People buy the nicest car they can afford? Their is a huge difference between saving all the time and being able to just focus on your life and not worry about finances. To live comfortably in the UK you will need about £4000/month To live with dignity you will need at least £1100/month but life won't be easy and you wont manage to stay out of debt.

The average gross salary in the UK is around £27,000-£28,000 per year but how good this is depends on where in the country you are living. Somewhere close to London will see an above average cost of living, whilst living in some remote part of Wales or the North East England for example will mean a cost of living well below the average and therefore more money in your pocket from your wages, so easier to achieve a higher standard of living. Something London does have in its favour is an abundance of opportunity and things to do, plus a very affordable & very extensive public transport network which enables you to get anywhere in greater London relatively cheaply and easily.

It depends on where in the UK. Accommodation is likely to be the largest item in the budget. Closer to London or some other large cities and accommodation costs escalate dramatically. Near the South coast my sons paid about £500 a month each for a house share but this could easily double or triple for some areas of London. Further North, accommodation tends to be somewhat cheaper but can be difficult to find in university towns. Travel can also be quite expensive: people often spend £80 to £400 a month commuting. Commuting into London on a daily basis can be particularly expensive. If you shop wisely and are prepared to cook, food and household costs can probably be keep to about £200 -£250 a month. The average household utility bill is about £100 per month, All these figures assume a fairly basic lifestyle and, of course, exclude much socialising , eating out or maintaining a vehicle.

OMG! First of all! Excuse me for my English ! How can you Run a house of 6 on the UK with just 1500£??? In my town that is un the North of Spain a house like yours will be at least 750€ and it’s a low standard. In property you can buy a house like that (detached) in a near village just 5 mins from downtown for at least 200k€. An internet + house telephone + mobiles phones bills = 100€ Food is cheaper at Spain and with better quality but you cant do it for 6 with , at least, 400€, buying meat and good products. Electricity bills for a 4 bedRoom house at least 75€ (low standard). Water like 20€. 250€ for meals , holiday , enjoy with your children? What can you do with that ?Im not counting the council tax , car tax , gas, Books and educations for children( so expensive un Spain like 150–250€ per child) and an a amount of bills that make me think , If anybody can’t run a house of 6 with 1500€ at Spain ( living good) , how can you run a house of six in the UK , that is supossed to be a more expensive country that Spain? sorry for my English

Totally depends where you are in the uk and on the house prices etc I’m very lucky, I live in the West Midlands near Coventry and Birmingham, where the house prices are low, for example a 3 bed semi is probably £150,000-£200,000, and I’m on an above average wage for an unskilled worker on about £40,000 working at a local car manufacturing plant, and I bought my place off the council for £36,000 so my mortgage is less than my yearly salary, but no people on half my wage with £200,000 mortgages with a partner.

I'm a South African expat living in a small town in West Sussex for the past 6 years with my spouse and 2 teenage children. My monthly expenses are: Rent £1300 - standard for a 3 bed house in the area; Council tax is £165; Water/waste is £69; Gas and electricity is £180; Car and insurance £305; Fuel £120; Food and entertainment £800. Phone, TV and broadband £58; TV licence £13–20. There are other expenses that I have not listed because I'd consider them luxuries. We could also save on water and electricity costs if we really have to. I recently had to pay close to £15000 for my family's Leave to Remain visas. 2 years ago, visa fees cost £1200 per person and before emigrated there was a visa cost, which my employer sponsored. Currently, Citizenship will cost around £1400 per person if we decide to take this route in about a years time. If you are from outside the EU, it is a costly affair to live in some areas of the UK. Do your research before emigrating.

I live in south yorkshire and rent and bills are alot lower than down south i get around £1400–1500 a month on disabillity benifits and thats enough for me to live on i pay around £68.50 a week for rent and £49 a week for living costs this will be different for other people that eqautes to around £117.50 a week or £470 a month for everything so thats £470 out of my £1500 budget so im left with around £1030 i get around £600 a month as an ‘allowence’ i tend to only really use about £300 out of that maybe less i dont mnave my whole money for myself a provider does this for me so im able to do well on what i get i get to go cinemas and stuff once alls back to normal

Totally different viewpoint. For London, if you want to not have to worry about buying what you want, I think a gross household income of around £100k would fit the bill. This will allow you to live, have holidays, eat out, run a car,pay for buying a home and save a little. Because of the way that people are taxed in the UK, earning above £100K means you pay a lot of tax.

It all depends on where you live, how you live and what your priorities are. Hundreds and thousands are often required if you want a house, car, all mod cons, go out, have holidays, socialise etc. If you have less you spend less and you manage on less, just ask anyone who has the state pension and perhaps a bit more. You still 'live', you budget everything and just don't do 'extras' like more heat then you need, cars, holidays, every new gadget etc and hope for the best.

Living costs are very different in different parts of the UK. I guess it mostly depends on where you want to live - and what type and size of accommodation. If your salary is more than 3x times your housing costs (rent/ mortgage + all bills) - then I would say you make a good salary. However - your living situation is up to you - what cost me £350 per month when I was living in Leeds - costs me £900 in London (similar size accommodation of similar quality, similar area, and so on and so forth)

It really depends on the city and the geographical region, as UK is huge. I can give information from London. The rent of 1 bedroom flats vary between £1200–1500 (not that good ones), 2 bedrooms (1600–1900 and even more), that increases for 3 and 4, but difficult to find a decent house in the centre obviously, only flat is a better option. Add the council tax of 150–200 and even more depending on the part of the city (borough) you live in.

The average price for a semi-detached house is about £230,000. Assuming you have a 10% deposit of £23,000 saved, that means you'd need a mortgage of £207,000 (call it £210,000 after fees etc). A standard mortgage is 3 times a single salary, or 2 times a couple's joint salary, making a good income £70,000 for a single earner, or about £105,000 split between a couple). If you want to live in London, you'll need considerably more.

I live in East ham, here in a PG with food. Your weekly rent is 80 and 30 for food. For 4 weeks it is 440. My transport is from Zone 1 to 3 — 160 in all 600 is bare minimum. After this usually we spend around 200 -300 more. In all 800 is bare minimum If you choose to live in a different place rent varies so will you expense.

it depends where you live and what your aspirations are. Also if you own your home or have a family. In London you are probably looking at approaching £100k but elsewhere perhaps £50k. However, loads of people have a comfortable life on salaries well below these.

I live just outside london. This is a rough breakdown of me and my wifes expenses, Rent, 4bed £1650, Childcare £1400, Council Tax £180, Utilities £150, Internet Phones and Sky £150, Cars £500, Insurance £145, Food £800, Petrol £200, Misc £100 total is about £5300 per month. That’s without entertainment. To live comfortably near London with a family you want to earn as a household £120k. Up north you could probably live on 60% of that.

Depends on your circumstances. If you can put 5 percent or more down on a property your life will get easier. Rent is a trap, as soon as you get a 4 bedroom home on rent you can forget ever owning a property. If 2 people work in the same household you can live quite comfortably. If you live on your own you can only afford cramped accommodation. If two people work you can have one person's salary for saving, entertainment or holidays. You get a lot of time off in the UK.

I live in Nottm pay rent of £400 (as I live with my mother also she gets no benefits as I'm living with her ),if I had my own place pay £500- £700 for flat or poss house then council tax (£100+), then amenities and lastly food so monthly with my mother about £600 if own place around £1000+ so a reasonable monthly wage about £1400 -1600 after tax.
A good salary is £77,000 a year per person. At this point your happiness stops increasing with your wage. You can live comfortably but you arent rich.
£10 million/day is a good salary in the UK.

As a rule, in view of work by a significant destitution philanthropy, a solitary individual needs at least around £850/month after expense barring rent to have what most British individuals would think about a better than average essential life. That incorporates some social exercises, nourishment, transport, garments, etc.

The UK has a legally enforced ‘Minimum Wage’ and a slightly higher ‘Living Wage’ that is supported by unions. That will answer your question for most of the country. Then add at least 50% for living in London.

It depends where in the UK. In London you will need at least £1800 after tax for one person if you leave in greater London meaning out of central London. Rents and public transportation fares are higher than anywhere else.
